name: Grasé, Jan Carl Gijsbert aan Verwey, Albert | 1884-04-11

Transcription.text:
¶Wellington House
Eton Rd N.W.
April 11th '84

And so I did receive a letter from you at last! Grave apprehension haunted me, crushed me in fact, as to the state of the Nassaukade. Had it been swallowed and swept away from the face of the earth & adjoining windmills by God's wrath, he being discontented with the proceedings of making more straight canals in A'dam or had my good friend buried himself under a heap of papers ¶on the AD.L&D.Socy? or had he eloped with some of the 'dear little things'? Dreadful uncertainty. You wicked fellow, you kept me in. I am only half satisfied with yr letter. This about a girl after all. I see, & I still have my misgivings as to yr present condition. But what is the good of me being uneasy about you when I am not a whit better myself. A fortnight or three weeks ago, I made acquaintance with a lovely darling, as sweet as almonds, (at least when they are sweet.) We both go to the same ¶church & offer our praises to God.
    But about Church! I shall forward a nice little book to you to-morrow by Chs Bradlaugh Mistakes of Moses, he calls it. You don't know it very likely & I intend to have it circulating amongst my Dutch friends for the good of their souls. The dear little book is worth 10 Bibles & more than that.
    If Jesus had eer lived in London in the year of grace or (disgrace) 1880 with Charles B. he would ¶have told his disciples [not?] [with?] any: 'Good News', I bet.    
    Holidays have begun. Holy, holy, holy, everything breathes religion in this damned country of hypocrisy. If there is a devil he must be an Englishman, at least the one who tempted Jesus in the desert must have been a John Bull. [xxxxx] to day in commemorations of the death of the good young man.
    Hot-cran. buns, for breakfast & the shops closed!
    ¶We have been enjoying here up till to-day a fresh edition of a London spring; heat, cold, heat. fog, rain. easterly wind, backward trees, smoky dirty grass, cricket & football played together & a tremendous fire, the traditional spring-fire. I dare say you read about it in the papers. It goes without saying now, that everyone feels happy, jumps & dances, falls in love & gets out of it in a fortnight or three weeks. (I omit birds, as I only see 3 here. three habitual visitors starlings. 5 sparrows excepted.)
    How are the Dutch hens? prosperous, ponderously thick with eggs. I dare say you have begun yr eggmeals by the time this letter reaches you. I do not believe Easter stimulates an Englishman's appetite.
    ¶I intended at first to come & spend my holidays in A'dam. But I shall not see the place till May 3rd 12. AM; till May 5th 5 PM. A short stay. Just for Lamsvelt's parents. Their silver wedding festival is coming off on the 3rd & they want me to be present.
    Up till now I have been busily arranging matters for the C.P. Exhib. I had my photo taken yesterday for photographic passes. The Exhib will open with a fine concert of 2500 performers, & a band of 250. ¶so much as it does [xxx]. There deep feeling finds & seeks a very appropriate [sent?] in decorating churches & volunteers' reviews.
    I am not content with myself just now & I'll stop this.

Truly yrs as ever
G. Grasé.

I have given up reading my own handwriting & now leave it to the addressed.
